data.title: HANNA SCHYGULLA CHARTS A FRESH COURSE
data.meta_description:
Among the day's major European film stars, the German actress Hanna Schygulla, long associated with the films of the late director Rainer Werner Fassbinder, has emerged as one of the most visible and luminous figures in international cinema. In the recent years, her cool, enigmatic beauty and her fluid, subtly modulated acting have prompted a wide variety of well- known directors to cast her in their films, usually to stunning effect.

John Gruen is a frequent contributor to Arts and Leisure.  Two of Miss Schygulla's starring films were important entries in the recently concluded New York Film Festival, presented by The Film Society of Lincoln Center: Marco Ferreri's controversial ''Story of Piera'' (for which Miss Schygulla received the Best Actress Award at this year's Cannes Film Festival), and Jean-Luc Godard's cryptic ''Passion,'' now at Cinema Studio 2.

Recently on view at the Festival Theater on 57th street was Fassbinder's 15-hour-long ''Berlin Alexanderplatz,'' in which Miss Schygulla plays a central role. The actress has also been seen in Ettore Scola's ''Nuit de Varennes,'' which just completed a long run at the Lincoln Plaza. Later this fall, she will appear in ''Sheer Madness,'' a film by Margarethe von Trotta, and she has just completed ''A Love in Germany,'' directed by Andrzej Wajda, scheduled for an early 1984 release.
data.text:
Among the day's major European film stars, the German actress Hanna Schygulla, long associated with the films of the late director Rainer Werner Fassbinder, has emerged as one of the most visible and luminous figures in international cinema. In the recent years, her cool, enigmatic beauty and her fluid, subtly modulated acting have prompted a wide variety of well- known directors to cast her in their films, usually to stunning effect.

John Gruen is a frequent contributor to Arts and Leisure. Two of Miss Schygulla's starring films were important entries in the recently concluded New York Film Festival, presented by The Film Society of Lincoln Center: Marco Ferreri's controversial ''Story of Piera'' (for which Miss Schygulla received the Best Actress Award at this year's Cannes Film Festival), and Jean-Luc Godard's cryptic ''Passion,'' now at Cinema Studio 2.

Recently on view at the Festival Theater on 57th street was Fassbinder's 15-hour-long ''Berlin Alexanderplatz,'' in which Miss Schygulla plays a central role. The actress has also been seen in Ettore Scola's ''Nuit de Varennes,'' which just completed a long run at the Lincoln Plaza. Later this fall, she will appear in ''Sheer Madness,'' a film by Margarethe von Trotta, and she has just completed ''A Love in Germany,'' directed by Andrzej Wajda, scheduled for an early 1984 release.

During a visit to New York to participate in the festivities of the New York Film Festival, Hanna Schygulla (pronounced

Shee-goo-lah),

caused something of a stir when, following the press screening of Ferreri's ''Story of Piera,'' she strongly defended the director's highly unorthodox view of motherhood. After being verbally attacked by several shocked members of the audience who considered the film immoral, she announced that ''Piera,'' for all its outrageous content, gave a fairly accurate image of children as survivors. She pointed out that parents who overprotect their children usually deprive them of the necessary strength to face life.

Later, during an interview in her hotel suite, Miss Schygulla, who speaks fluent English, commented on the episode:

''It's amazing how certain people will react to things that are out of the norm. I mean, they will think and fantasize about such things, but when it's shown to them in the form of an actual image, they will recoil and feel threatened. Of course, Ferreri's films have never been easy. 'La Grande Bouffe' and 'The Last Woman' did not exactly deal with easy subjects. But for me, playing the mother in 'Piera' was incredibly fulfilling. I went into it knowing that the subject of incest was very touchy. But it was a role where, for once, the character was speeding ahead of me. You see, I need to be in films that say something and to play characters who really live out their feelings. That's when I feel I'm being stretched and challenged.''
